chapter.htmlHeader: How common is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Reported mental health problems in students are increasing in prevalence. Between 2006/2007 and 2015/2016, the number of first-year students disclosing a mental health condition to their higher education institution increased almost five-fold. 
  • In 2018/2019, 4.3% of UK students (5.3% of females and 2.8% of males) disclosed a mental health condition to their higher education institutions. However, this is lower than prevalence figures obtained from anonymous surveys and is likely to be an underestimate of the true prevalence, due to:
    • The perceived stigma associated with officially declaring a mental health condition.
    • The fact that mental health problems must be declared when applying to university in the ‘disability/special needs’ section of the UCAS form. Some young people with mental health problems may not view themselves as having a disability, do not have a formally diagnosed condition, or do not see their difficulties as long term.
  • In a 2019 survey of 21,000 students from over 140 universities in the UK:
    • 42.3% stated that they had had a serious personal, emotional, behavioural, or mental health problem for which they needed professional help.
      • Students among this cohort were statistically significantly more likely to identify as non-binary gender, and/or be in the third year of university, aged between 19 and 20 years, from the UK, and ethnically white. Females were also at greater risk than males.
      • For the majority of people with mental health problems, onset was in school and for only 1 in 10, developed while at university. 
    • 26.6% reported a pre-existing mental health diagnosis, with the most common being depression (12%) and anxiety disorders (11.2%).
      • For those with a pre-existing diagnosis, 81.1% stated they were currently affected by symptoms.
      • Pre-existing mental health diagnosis was statistically significantly more likely among people who identified as non-binary gender, followed by females.
    • 8.1% reported using drugs or alcohol in order to fall asleep at night.
    • 56.5% reported some thoughts of self-harm.
    • 1.7% reported that they often or always had suicidal thoughts.
  • Previous surveys have also identified high rates of mental health problems among students.
    • In 2013, an online questionnaire commissioned by the National Union of Students found (based on 1285 responses):
      • 16% of students had a current mental health diagnosis.
      • 26% had experienced mental health difficulties. Of these:
        • 80% reported stress.
        • 66% reported being consistently unhappy.
        • 55% reported anxiety.
        • 49% reported depression.
        • 45% reported anger.
        • 38% reported episodes of panic.
    • Similar results were found in a 2016 YouGov poll, which questioned 1061 students and reported that 26.5% experienced mental health difficulties.
  • The prevalence estimates provided by such polls are, however, likely to be imprecise due to factors including:
    • People with mental health conditions may be more motivated to participate than people without, meaning that overall prevalence estimates may be artificially elevated.
    • Particular demographic groups may be over-represented among participants, while others are under-represented. The 2019 survey of 21,000 students found that participation was more common among:
      • First-year students.
      • Females.
      • Students aged 18 or 19 years.
      • People whose ethnicities were ‘White’ and ‘Asian’. However, the prevalence of respondents with ‘Black’, ‘Mixed’, and ‘Other’ ethnicities was broadly consistent with the higher education population in general.
    • In some demographic groups (such as males and people from particular cultural backgrounds), recognition and/or candid expression of mental health problems may be less likely. 
    • International students participating in this type of research must have a good command of English, and be particularly motivated by the topic of mental health, and therefore may not be representative of the whole international community. 

[Institute for Employment Studies and REAP, 2015; Institute for Public Policy Research, 2017; British Psychological Society, 2020; Hubble, 2020; The Insight Network, 2020]
